2120.text: You know, if you really hate them and want them to go to hell and cut them off,

2124.text: then just make a big deal over things like that.

2131.text: Again, it's making the kingdom of God look like it's Pharisaical

2136.text: with a few laws and regulations.

2138.text: Back in our church, we used to have a Christmas day service but we stopped it this year.

2144.text: We have our carol service before where we invite people to,

2148.text: but Christmas day, we realize, is a time when the Christians can go to be with their lost family members,

2157.text: (because it's a great offense otherwise to them,)

2168.text: Another way in which a Christian can be like a pharisee is viewing holiness like this:

2181.text: Becoming unnatural and having no interest in people's lives around us.

2188.text: I want you to notice in our text, Paul still speaks of his countrymen as MY countrymen.

2194.text: He doesn't say my former countrymen but now I'm a citizen of Heaven.

2200.text: But they are still his countrymen.

2203.text: Lloyd-Jones said that there are Christians today

2207.text: who think it's wrong to take an interest in local or national affairs,

2211.text: or even that it's wrong to vote and things like that.

2215.text: He said that's just a bad view of sanctification;

2218.text: that's trying to come totally out of the world.

2220.text: We're supposed to be in the world but not of it, being salt and light there.

2228.text: And I mentioned that because a lot of Christians build up an unnecessary wall with lost people

2234.text: by shunning everything from day to day life, as if I'm too holy for that.

2242.text: You know, you go to your lost family members,

2244.text: they might be talking about sports or something on the news, and it's just, "Ooooh!"

2250.text: And it just come across as unnatural.

2255.text: There are some Christians who leave a bad impression because

2261.text: they think you have to separate from everything in culture.

2265.text: It's been great going through Genesis back home.

2267.text: We realized there Abraham had a winning party which was some pagan party they did.

2275.text: Then we realized circumcision didn't start with the Jews.

2278.text: It was really a pagan rite that God took and christianized,

2282.text: because it meant a specific point in a specific culture.

2287.text: So you can do that too.

2291.text: You see, culture is not necessarily evil.

2295.text: We see in the book of Revelation there many tribes and tongues around the throne of God,

2301.text: all with their own cultures, worshiping God.

2304.text: You know, one of the worst things certain British missionary organizations did at one time

2312.text: was to try and convert the world to 19th century Victorianism

2317.text: and make everyone act and dress like Victorian Englishmen.

2321.text: I mean, convert them to Christ, Yes.

2324.text: But you don't have to make an exuberant African act like a stiff, reserved Englishman.

2333.text: Which leads me to another way one can view holiness like a Pharisee.

2342.text: And that is, having an unscriptural definition between the sacred and the secular.

2351.text: How many people fall into this today?

2354.text: In the Old Testament, all the priests did all the holy work and the secular was separate.

2360.text: But in the New Covenant, you see, it's not like that.

2364.text: In the New Covenant, we are all priests, reigning with God.

2369.text: We are all offering up our priestly service.

2372.text: Now, how are we expected to live this?

2376.text: Are we all expected to become full-time preachers?

2379.text: No, we are to become priests in our daily lives.

2382.text: In your workplace, we are told, do your secular work for the Lord, and you will receive a reward.

2390.text: You know, motherhood, raising the children for the Lord.

2395.text: Whether we eat or drink or whatever we do, do all to the glory of God.

2404.text: A dear brother, (I almost hate using this example because he's so dear to me,

2412.text: but it really helps so many people,)

2416.text: but he once preached for us and he did very well,

2421.text: except one thing he said and I took issue with.

2426.text: And he said some Christians have a 15-minute devotion time,

2431.text: they have a 15-minute time in the Word,

2434.text: and then he said, "But that's all they give to God.

2437.text: That's all they think God is worth -15 minutes."

2441.text: And I said to him, "Brother, no that is wrong."

2445.text: I said take, for example, the example of a Christian mother.

2450.text: She may have a 15-minute devotion time, but that's not all she gives to God.

2457.text: She then gets the children ready for the Lord.

2459.text: She then runs the house for the Lord.

2462.text: She doesn't just give 15-minutes to the Lord, she gives her whole day to the Lord.

2468.text: And then I added, "Even when she's looking at a friend's baby photos on Facebook."

2478.text: You see what that is, it's this distinction from the sacred and the secular there.

2487.text: We are not all to be monks and just read the Word all the time,

2491.text: but I'd rather people read less and lived more.

2500.text: One last thing, and I think this is also very helpful.

2507.text: It certainly helped brethren in our church and me personally in being around unbelievers.

2513.text: And that is, when you become a Christian, you do not cease to be natural.

2523.text: The Christian is natural, but is more than the natural.

2528.text: He's more than the natural but never less.

2530.text: Take, for instance, Paul's burden here.

2535.text: In one sense, it is a natural burden to want to reach those you were closely affiliated with before salvation.

2543.text: But it's more than the natural after the way they treated him.

2548.text: Jesus told us we're not just to love those who treat us well

2552.text: (our friends, those who love us, our family members)

2557.text: but we are to love our enemies.

2559.text: But when He said that, He wasn't telling us we're not to love [those who are close to us].

2566.text: He wasn't telling us we are to be unnatural;

2568.text: we are to be natural but more than the natural.

2574.text: You see, a lot of Christians spend a lot of time and effort trying to suppress being natural,

2585.text: and act in an unnatural way.

2588.text: It gives them a false impression of Christianity.

2591.text: They pretend they are too high and holy to talk about normal things with people.

2596.text: Or if someone tells a joke -

2597.text: and I don't mean a dirty joke, but I don't mean a real easy one either -

2603.text: if a believer tells it, that's fine.

2604.text: But if an unbeliever tells it, you know, "I'm too holy to laugh."

2614.text: You see, people get confused about this

2616.text: because Scripture, of course, speaks of the natural man (who does not accept the things of God)

2622.text: But he's not saying we cease to be natural there,

2625.text: but as a Christian you're not governed by the natural realm.

2628.text: You have the Holy Spirit so you're more than the natural.

2631.text: But you don't cease to be natural.

2633.text: There's many more verses I can prove that point from,

2636.text: but for time, I will just give you a few closing applications.

2644.text: These are things we've experienced back home in Manchester or in Switzerland.

2649.text: I will sometimes hear Christians talk about going visiting their lost parents

2654.text: or spending some time with them or other lost family members, as if it's some great chore.

2660.text: You know, "We have nothing to talk about. We can't talk about anything."

2668.text: And, I generally point out to people because normally this is asked about.

2673.text: And I remember one time, a brother was asking me

2676.text: and there were three Christian girls cooking in the kitchen.

2681.text: And I said, "Listen to their conversation.

2685.text: They are not speaking about Scripture at the moment, they are talking about normal things.

2692.text: You see, my point was, you talk about those things with Christians,

2698.text: so why can't you talk about those things with non-Christians?

2703.text: It gives a completely false impression of what Christianity is,

2713.text: because you're not like that when you're around Christians.

2719.text: It's only when Christians are around unbelievers they can become tense if they fall into this.

2727.text: Another time I see this is, sometimes, a Christian would say,

2733.text: "I've got to go to a family wedding this Saturday,

2737.text: (a lost family wedding or some family party or some other event,)"

2742.text: and then they'll say in their next word, "but it's a chance to witness to them."

2748.text: Now listen, I am not against sharing the Gospel with them if the Lord opens the opportunity there.

2754.text: But you see what's wrong there?

2757.text: They can't just enjoy and show love and be kind to their family members.

2765.text: They have to give an apology to other Christians why they are going.

2770.text: And so what normally happens is they go to those things

2772.text: and they are on edge all the time

2773.text: because they've told everyone else that they are going to preach the Gospel to someone.

2778.text: And so, they either make a mess of it doing it mechanically

2782.text: or they go home feeling condemned because they never opened their mouth.

2791.text: The only impression they gave to everyone else is "Wow, that person is really on edge."

2799.text: I think it was brother Ryan Skinner who told us the other day

2804.text: that sometimes when Christians can be like that with lost people,

2807.text: the impression they give is like the Children of the Corn coming at them.

2817.text: But you know, when you're reaching, when you're around lost people,

2824.text: you don't have to witness to them all the time or every time.

2834.text: You know, those you're with regularly, again, show them your life first.

2839.text: Show them a change - how kind and warm you are - and they'll see a difference.

2844.text: You know, I hear this phrase today, "You can't live the Gospel."

2848.text: Has that person never read 1st Peter?

2850.text: The whole book is about living the Gospel,

2852.text: as the brother said before, "We are the fifth gospel."

2862.text: It's a lot harder, it takes a lot more love to live the Gospel around people

2867.text: than just to say a few words and run.

2871.text: You know, tick that box and leave them.

2878.text: Again, I always ask that question, What impression of the kingdom of God am I giving unbelievers?

2886.text: Am I giving them an impression that being a Christian looks something like a Pharisee,

2895.text: or that I really love them and I'm kind to them as Christ was to me.

2899.text: That it's a relationship with a person, it's joy.

2918.text: Our Father, I know these words, these truths have been so helpful in my own life

2928.text: and for other brothers and sisters in Europe.

2933.text: And I know, what was once tense relationships, the walls have come down so quickly

2942.text: by applying these truths of persevering and not being quickly to cut off and defriend;

2950.text: and just being normal, natural, taking an interest in people, and showing love.

2961.text: People have even come to Christ

2966.text: who was once separated from the Christian by an impression of a pharisee.

2972.text: I pray You would help the brothers and sisters here, all who hear this word,

2975.text: help us Lord to be in their lives, to be reaching our lost family members, neighbors,

2981.text: those whom You put our way.

2991.text: We need Your Holy Spirit to have this love like Paul,

2999.text: so we don't quickly cut people off.

3003.text: We thank You that You did not cut us off.

3006.text: That, Lord, how badly we have been even since our conversion, never mind before.

3016.text: And yet, You persevered with us and You were cut off in our place.

3020.text: We praise You in Jesus' name, Amen.
